job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Easton, PA
pros: Professors were very open to new research avenues with their own research or yours. Very understanding if you can't make a certain deadline because you are a student first.
cons: Because it's a small campus, it may be hard to find research opportunities.

review_title: Pay is atrocious but a nice place overall
pros: It's a nice campus and the benefits are solid.
cons: The pay is bad. Each staff position basically has a workload for two people. Many staff have faculty members as bosses and they are hit or miss personality- and ability-wise (personally I work for two people who are enormously difficult, amd tend to take out their frustrations and incompetences on me).

pros: Students are passionate about school

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Easton, PA
pros: Coworkers really truly deeply care about individual students. We know these people and continue to have relationships after they enroll at the college.
cons: While overall there is good flexibility within the department, the nature of the job requires intense focus and attention during specific times of the year, including the holidays. Although the college closes and employees have lots of extra vacation, the admissions team is actually working furiously through the holiday.

job_title: Senior Associate Director in Easton, PA
pros: The Lafayette College community is vibrant, passionate, and supportive. There are ample opportunities to gain experience in different areas of the college and/or to grow within a specific area.
cons: Change often moves slowly in higher education, and Lafayette is no exception.

pros: Small, tight knit liberal arts school
cons: May be too small for those who enjoy a large school environment

pros: Ability to design and implement research projects.

pros: Good time depends on Professor

pros: Beautiful campus, smart students, great facilities.

pros: Small campus, good benefits, great students.

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Easton, PA
pros:
* Some departments have very supportive chairs, collegial faculty, and a wonderful, equitable departmental culture.

* Students are generally very bright and motivated.

* Some research funding is available to contingent faculty, and more substantial funding is available to tenure line faculty.

* Competitive salary and benefits amongst small liberal arts colleges.

* Beautiful campus and facilities.

* Support for faculty's continuing development as educators in the form of grants and workshops.

* Faculty has freedom to design courses around their research.

* The new president is putting in excellent work on improving conditions for faculty and students.
cons:
* Some departments need to work more on creating a more welcoming, equitable work culture for diverse faculty.

* Upper administration sometimes seems to be at odds with what department chairs, faculty, and students want and need - increases to class sizes and less diverse administration than a year ago.

* The college desperately needs to hire academic advisors, deans, tutors, and counselors to support students and faculty.

* STEM faculty and students are shown favoritism in funding, increases to tenure line positions, priority to determine scheduling for courses, ability to ask for more required courses for their majors than other departments, and other resources, to the point where humanities, social sciences, and arts programs struggle to enroll students and attract majors.

* No kosher kitchens on campus for students or faculty with religious dietary restrictions.

cons: The salary is based on Easton minimum wage

review_title: Great Place but lots of nepotism
pros: Great education benefits, access to library and arts events. Salary is stagnant with little raises.
cons: Nepotism abounds here and if you are not in the club you can be pushed out. Think fraternity/sorority environment. Some departments eat their babies. Union staff are treated like second-class citizens and left out. Poor upper management.

pros: I get to work and go to school, surrounded by wonderful people
cons: I have to graduate soon!

review_title: great small college to work at
pros: Beautiful campus, good benefits, students are generally really intelligent and sweet, colleagues are generally friendly. The school is small enough that you can really make a positive difference in the campus community.
cons: Faculty and administrative shared governance structure is somewhat ineffective; extremely liberal political climate among faculty does not tolerate even moderate dissenting views and is somewhat hypocritical given the cost of the college. Staff salaries have been flat for 3 years.

pros: Fun teacher will allow for a decent time.

review_title: Solid employer, but expect to feel underappreciated
job_title: Higher Education Program Manager in Easton, PA
pros: Some departments/programs offer flexible scheduling; campus is very pleasant; tuition benefits for children are amazing benefit.
cons: Anemic raises barely keep up with inflation (and DON'T in some years); staff and lower-level admins get different treatment than faculty, and climate survey data gathered by outside contractors confirms staff feels underappreciated. Benefits are based on single employee with no kids; expect to pay $$$ to have your family covered.

review_title: Avoid like plague for visiting professorships
job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Lincolnton, NC
pros: Good salary, opportunity to teach, great 'mental' workout.
cons:
No job security. Management listens to students and not to faculty. Very less power to faculty. Internal politics and nepotism among engineering faculty at least. The politics in engineering department is really crass. Professors fight like students and students have so much more power than professors that I was warned by my colleagues - don't mess (give lower grades) with students. This place is going to humble you down as you will high school graduates wielding the whip on PhDs ! The evaluate you and if your first semester's evaluations are not good - well, you are doomed. I was an immigrant and they fired me just based on my first semester evaluations. My second semester evaluations were good but were not even considered. I was an engineering professor and was not allowed to use laboratories for my research which somewhat killed my research. The laboratory staff taunted me and fought with me, complaining to the chair, who took their sides ! So a very very bad experience. Please avoid at all cost. I had to teach five courses in my first semester and I was like a donkey of teaching !

A summary of everything: the college has student photographs in the hallways instead of the faculty. And whereas faculty have restricted access on weekends, student keys open all doors :)

job_title: Tutor Lafayette College in Easton, PA
pros: They have the best students!
cons: They don't pay their tutors much.

job_title: Wall Climbing Assistant in Easton, PA
pros: Small school and thus not overburdened with work. Personalized attention is given to students and great assistance is provided for students.
cons: Limited working hours and thus hard to earn enough money from this job. The job is also too competitive thus hard to get. Many people give up in the process.

pros: Understanding supervisors for when you needed to leave work early, communicative work environment within the office, and work alongside a diverse and energetic population of students.
cons: Some times there are long hours and interdepartmental communication can be difficult. Also, working on weekends happens more often than at other jobs.

review_title: Most student workers aren't paid enough
pros: Most of the college staff are wonderful to work with and make the job more fun. Some of the positions have a small salary increase each semester that you work with them.
cons: Most students are paid very low wages - they meet the Pennsylvania minimum wage, but are very low compared to other places, and the administration has been slow to change that.

review_title: Wonderful people - love my time here running a program at Lafayette.
pros: The faculty here are of very high caliber. The environment is warm and community-oriented as well. You don't get that kind of experience at a research university.
cons: The surrounding area - downtown Easton, not great.
